Name: Agility and Stamina
Description: Stamina is a secondary resource used to pay for moves alongside Energy. Agility is a stat that determines the rate that you gain stamina, and it is proportional to Max EP.
InfoBox: Stamina is a secondary resource used to pay for moves alongside Energy. Agility is a stat that determines the rate that you gain stamina, and it is proportional to Max EP.<line><line>Agility is calculated by adding 7 to your Max EP and then dividing by a certain factor and then rounding up. This factor is 12 for Wilex and 16 for Luna.<line><line>If you use a move whose stamina cost is higher than your Agility, you won't get any stamina next turn. The character in front also has their agility increased by 50%.

Name: Enemy Behavior
Description: Enemies tend to target the front character twice as often as they target the back character. Enemy behavior also tends to be deterministic.
InfoBox: Enemies tend to target the front character twice as often as they target the back character.<line><line>Enemy behavior also tends to be deterministic, though their behavior may depend on what other enemies are in the formation and what turn it is, with a few enemies acting different based on your hp.

Name: Item Drops
Description: Enemies will drop items once every 4 battles, but this rate goes up to once every 2 battles if you got no XP from the battle.
InfoBox: Enemies will drop items once every 4 battles, but this rate goes up to once every 2 battles if you got no XP from the battle.<line><line>Items will drop more often if you have 4 or less items in your inventory, and are guaranteed to drop if you have 2 or less items in your inventory.<line><line>Curse badges will also increase the item drop rate.<line><line>Certain strong enemies will always drop items. Each enemy type has an item it can drop if you start a fight with it in the overworld.<line><line>Stacking enough effects that increase item drop rate will cause the drop rate to go above 100%, making it possible to get multiple items from one battle.

Name: Curse Badges
Description: Curse Badges increase the difficulty of the game by multiplying enemy stats by a certain amount and changing their moves in a certain way.
InfoBox: Curse Badges increase the difficulty of the game by multiplying enemy stats by a certain amount and changing their moves in a certain way, while also increasing the rewards from battle.<line><line>More specifically, enemy Max HP, Attack, Coin drops and Experience drops are all multiplied. Items will also drop more often from normal enemy battles as well. Attacks are guaranteed to deal at least 1 more damage than with the previous curse level (i.e. with Super Curse, all attacks will deal at least 1 more damage than normal.)<line><line>Boss fights are expected to be barely possible with Mega Curse, requiring very advanced strategy and often requiring grinding to the maximum possible stats you can obtain as well as cooking an inventory full of the best possible items.<line><line>Curse badges can be combined to be stacked together, but this will likely result in many required fights becoming completely impossible.

Name: Experience
Description: Experience points are earned by defeating enemies of a higher level than you. You level up once you obtain 100 of them.
InfoBox: Experience points are earned by defeating enemies of a higher level than you. You level up once you obtain 100 of them.<line><line>The amount of experience you get from a certain enemy is proportional to the difference between their level and yours. The experience bonus increases their level in the formula unless your level is equal or greater than theirs.<line><line>Enemies also drop more experience in encounters that start with more enemies.<line><line>The Curse badges will increase the experience enemies give out in proportion to their multiplier. However, each curse badge is guaranteed to add 1 to the experience the enemy gives out if the enemy gives out more than 0 experience.

Name: Contact Hazards
Description: Contact Hazards deal damage to you when you attack an enemy that has them. The only two types of contact hazards are ones that apply on direct contact and ones that apply on weapon moves.
InfoBox: Contact Hazards deal damage to you when you attack an enemy that has them. Different types of contact hazards include ones that apply on direct contact and ones that apply on weapon moves.<line><line>Contact hazards can never interrupt your moves, but they can reduce you to 0 hp. Each enemy can only deal contact damage to you once per turn, so a multihit move against a single target will only ever result in you taking damage a single time.<next>However, multitarget moves will result in you taking damage multiple times if you target multiple enemies that have contact hazards.

Name: Damage Reduction
Description: Effects that reduce incoming damage by a certain percentage stack do not stack linearly. Instead, each effect is given a certain number of Resistance Points (0.33 reduction = 1 point, 0.5 reduction = 2 points)
InfoBox: Effects that reduce incoming damage by a certain percentage stack do not stack linearly. Instead, each effect is given a certain number of Resistance Points (0.33 reduction = 1 point, 0.5 reduction = 2 points)<line><line>The formula for damage reduction is (R / (2 + R)) where R is the total number of resistance points you have (so 1 point is a reduction of 33%, 2 points is a reduction of 50% and so on.)

Name: Shield Payment
Description: Certain damage reduction effects require you to pay with a certain resource for each point of damage reduced. If you have multiple damage reduction effects active, you pay a lower amount.
InfoBox: Certain damage reduction effects require you to pay with a certain resource for each point of damage reduced. If you have multiple damage reduction effects active, you pay a lower amount.<line><line>More specifically, the amount you pay is multiplied by the ratio of how many resistance points are contributed by the effect divided by how many resistance points you have total.<next>For example, suppose you have 4 resistance points with 2 points coming from an effect you have to pay for. If the damage from a certain attack is reduced by 10, then the amount you pay is the same as if the damage was reduced by 5 and you only had the effect you had to pay for

Name: Status Effects
Description: Status Effects modify the behavior or stats of enemies. The duration of an effect is on the bottom right of the icon, and the potency is on the top left.
InfoBox: Status Effects modify the behavior or stats of enemies. The duration of an effect is on the bottom right of the icon, and the potency is on the top left. Ailments do not have potency, and tokens do not have duration. An effect with a duration of X is an effect with infinite duration, so it will last forever.<next><next>All effects on all entities will have their durations tick down after all enemies have moved. Certain effects will act when the durations tick down (i.e. something like Poison will deal damage at this time).

Name: Ailments
Description: Ailments are debilitating effects that usually prevent an enemy from moving or severely reduce their capabilities. Ailments are Berserk, Sleep, Paralyze, Dizzy, Freeze and Poison.
InfoBox: Ailments are debilitating effects that usually prevent an enemy from moving or severely reduce their capabilities. Ailments are Berserk, Sleep, Paralyze, Dizzy, Freeze and Poison.<line><line>Enemies can only have one ailment at a time. Each enemy type can have a different susceptibility to different ailments. Ailment inflicting moves against enemies work based on enemy HP and are not random. Enemies can also have different turn modifiers for each ailment, making them last longer or shorter against them.<next>Each enemy has a certain maximum number of turns they can be ailed, after which, it will become impossible to ail them again. Enemies also become less susceptible the more turns they have been ailed, proportional to their maximum ailment turns. <line><line>For example, an enemy with a maximum ailment turn count of 4 will become 25% less susceptible to all ailments for each turn of ailment inflicted against them.<line><line>Enemies can have moves that try to inflict ailments against you. You can block in order to reduce the duration of the inflicted ailment by 1.

Name: Buffs, Debuffs and Tokens
Description: Buffs, Debuffs and Tokens are temporary effects that can be applied in various ways.
InfoBox: Buffs, Debuffs and Tokens are temporary effects that can be applied in various ways. Buffs and Debuffs have duration and potency, while Tokens only have potency and they usually last indefinitely until certain conditions are met.<line><line>Unlike ailments, you can usually inflict an unlimited number of debuffs and negative tokens on enemies.<line><line>Like with ailments, enemies may have debuff inflicting moves, which you can reduce the duration of by blocking. You can also reduce the potency of negative tokens by blocking as well.

Name: Buff Stacking
Description: Attempting to apply a buff on a target that already has the same buff will cause the buff to have the potency of the stronger effect and a duration that is a certain amount longer than the stronger effect.
InfoBox: Attempting to apply a buff on a target that already has the same buff will cause the buff to have the potency of the stronger effect and a duration that is a certain amount longer than the stronger effect.<line><line>More specifically, the duration is calculated in the following way.<line>Effect Power = Duration A * Potency A + Duration B * Potency B<line>New Duration = Effect Power / New Potency (rounded down).<next>However, you are guaranteed to get at least 1 bonus turn.<next><next>It is not possible to stack buffs and debuffs with infinite duration. Tokens stack by adding potencies together, but there is a limit to stacking Focus and Absorb.

Name: Buff and Debuff Stacking
Description: Attempting to apply a buff on a target that has an opposite debuff (or vice versa) will cause the effect to have the duration of the effect with a longer duration and a potency in between the two effects.
InfoBox: Attempting to apply a buff on a target that has an opposite debuff (or vice versa) will cause the effect to have the duration of the effect with a longer duration and a potency in between the two effects.<line><line>More specifically, the potency is calculated in the following way (with Potency A and Duration A being the stronger effect)<line>New Potency = ((Duration A * Potency A) - (Duration B * Potency B)) / New Duration (rounded down)<next>However, stronger effect is guaranteed to be left with at least 1 potency. If one of the effects has infinite duration, then the potency will just be the potency of the stronger effect minus the weaker effect.

Name: Berserk
Description: Berserk is an ailment that increases the target's attack by 1 but reduces their defense by 1. The target is also forced to target the one who inflicted the ailment.
InfoBox: Berserk is an ailment that increases the target's attack by 1 but reduces their defense by 1. The target is also forced to target the one who inflicted the ailment. If this is not possible, they will target opponents normally. If an enemy inflicts you with Berserk, you will automatically use your base weapon move against it, or your base jump move if the weapon move can't be used.<next>However, if you become Berserk in some other way (or if you can't target the enemy that made you Berserk), you will alternate between using your base weapon move and your base jump move every other turn, targetting the frontmost target. In either case, you will block automatically while Berserk.<line><line>Berserk is the least useful ailment to inflict upon enemies, but it has some marginal usefulness if you want to make enemies target a specific character.

Name: Sleep
Description: Sleep is an ailment that prevents movement but causes the target to regenerate 10% of their Max HP every turn (clamped between 2 and 10 hp). Attacking a sleeping target wakes them up.
InfoBox: Sleep is an ailment that prevents movement, but causes the target to regenerate 10% of their Max HP every turn (clamped between 2 and 10 hp). Attacking a sleeping target wakes them up.<line><line>Inflicting Sleep upon enemies is useful at the start of battles, as the regeneration will not have any effect when the enemy is at max hp.

Name: Paralyze
Description: Paralyze is an ailment that reduces attack power by half.
InfoBox: Paralyze is an ailment that reduces attack power by half.<line><line>Inflicting Paralyze upon enemies is useful when you want to reduce the damage you take.

Name: Dizzy
Description: Dizzy is an ailment that causes all of the target's attacks to miss.
InfoBox: Dizzy is an ailment that causes all of the target's attacks to miss.<line><line>Dizzy is one of the best ailmentes to inflict upon enemies, but dizzy enemies can still perform actions that aren't attacks.

Name: Freeze
Description: Freeze is an ailment that prevents movement and reduces the target's defense by 1. Frozen targets become unfrozen when they take damage.
InfoBox: Freeze is an ailment that prevents movement and reduces the target's defense by 1. Frozen targets become unfrozen when they take damage.<line><line>Freezing enemies is very useful if you want to focus your attacks on other enemies.

Name: Poison
Description: Poison is an ailment that causes the target to take damage every turn equal to 10% of their Max HP (clamped between 2 and 10 hp).
InfoBox: Poison is an ailment that causes the target to take damage every turn equal to 10% of their Max HP (clamped between 2 and 10 hp).<line><line>While it doesn't restrict movement like the other ailmentes, Poison is still useful for dealing passive damage to enemies, or bypassing their defenses.

Name: Light Damage
Description: Light element is stronger against enemies at high hp, up to a 2x boost.
InfoBox: Light element is stronger against enemies at high hp, up to a 2x boost.<line><line>More specifically, the boost is a multiplier equal to (1 + (current hp / max hp)). Light damage is best used at the start of battle when all the enemies are at max hp.<line><line>If enemies are using light damage against you, you may want to avoid healing as long as possible in order to reduce the damage they deal.

Name: Dark Damage
Description: Dark element is stronger against enemies at low hp, up to a 2x boost.
InfoBox: Dark element is stronger against enemies at low hp, up to a 2x boost.<line><line>More specifically, the boost is a multiplier equal to (2 - (current hp / max hp)). Dark damage is best used against bosses when their hp is low.<line><line>If enemies are using Dark damage against you, you may want to heal more often than usual in order to avoid taking more damage.

Name: Earth Damage
Description: Earth element is 0.66x stronger against enemies that were hit this turn.
InfoBox: Earth element is 0.66x stronger against enemies that were hit this turn.<line><line>Earth damage is best used by the character moving second during your turn.<line><line>If enemies are using Earth damage against you, you may want to try to kill or ailment the other enemies so that the Earth damage user is the one that attacks first after your turn.

Name: Air Damage
Description: Air/Electric damage pierces defense except for specifically air/electric defense.
InfoBox: Air/Electric damage pierces defense except for specifically air/electric defense.<line><line>Air/Electric damage is best used against high defense enemies.<line><line>If enemies are using Air/Electric damage against you, you should avoid using defense boosts as they will not be useful.

Name: Water Damage
Description: Water element is 0.66x stronger against enemies that were not hit last turn.
InfoBox: Water element is 0.66x stronger against enemies that were not hit last turn.<line><line>Water damage is best used if you like to stack buffs on yourself before attacking.<line><line>If enemies are using Water damage against you, there may be situations where avoiding an attack would lead to you taking more damage from a water attack next turn.

Name: Fire Damage
Description: Fire damage gets boosted up to 0.66x based on how much the enemy took damage this turn and last turn.
InfoBox: Fire damage gets boosted up to 0.66x based on how much the enemy took damage this turn and last turn.<line><line>The boost is equal to the damage taken this turn and last turn, but it is capped at 0.66x the base damage of the boosted attack.<line><line>If enemies are using Fire damage against you, increasing your defense will be very effective as that will reduce how much their damage is boosted.

Name: Prismatic Damage
Description: Prismatic damage has no special modifiers, but enemies usually have no defense against Prismatic damage.
InfoBox: Prismatic damage has no special modifiers. However, enemy defense to Prismatic damage is equal to the lowest elemental defense that enemy has, which is usually 0 with Air/Electric damage.<line><line>Prismatic damage is very strong against enemies with major weaknesses to other elements.

Name: Void Damage
Description: Void damage has no special modifiers, and enemies usually have no defense against Void damage.
InfoBox: Void damage has no special modifiers, and enemies usually have no defense against Void damage. Enemy defense to Void damage is equal to the lowest elemental defense that enemy has, which is usually 0 with Air/Electric damage.<line><line>Void damage and Prismatic damage are very similar, but there are very few sources of these damage types.

Name: Advanced Elements
Description: In rare cases, elemental damage may use the "advanced" formulas instead of their normal ones, and the particle effects will be slightly different.
InfoBox: In rare cases, elemental damage may use the "advanced" formulas instead of their normal ones, and the particle effects will be slightly different.<next>Light: Damage multiplier =<line>2 - |Attacker HP % - Defender HP %|<line><line>Dark: Damage multiplier:<line>1 + |Attacker HP % - Defender HP %|<line><line>Earth: Each hit taken during their turn adds a bonus 0.33x up to a maximum of 2.33x at 3 hits.<next>Air: Deals additional damage based on enemy defense, up to a maximum of a 2x boost.<line><line>Water: Same as normal, but the bonus is 2x if you haven't attacked last turn as well as the enemy not being attacked last turn.<line><line>Fire: The damage treats attack reducing effects as buffs, the damage is also boosted based on the damage you have taken this turn and last turn, and the boost is capped at 1x the damage instead of 0.66x.

Name: Multi Element Attacks
Description: In general, the damage of a multi element attack receives all the boosts from the other types independently (except in the case of Light and Dark).
InfoBox: In general, the damage of a multi element attack receives all the boosts from the other types independently (except in the case of Light and Dark). In terms of calculating defense, the attack uses the lowest defense out of the elements it is.<line><line>If an attack deals both Light and Dark damage at the same time, the formula for the damage boost changes to be boosted based on whether the enemy is at low or high hp. More specifically, the formula for their damage together is:<line>Max((4 * Current HP / Max HP) - 2, 2 - (4 * Current HP / Max HP)).
